panic.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a sudden strong feeling of fear or nervousness that makes you unable to think clearly or behave sensibly
panic.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: a feeling of sheer panic (=complete panic)
She got into a panic when she couldn’t find the tickets.
The whole nation is in a state of panic following the attacks.
She suffers from terrible panic attacks.
panic.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a situation in which people are suddenly made very anxious, and make quick decisions without thinking carefully
panic.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: a wave of panic selling in Hong Kong
the recent panic over the safety of baby milk
panic.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a situation in which you have a lot to do and not much time to do it in
panic.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: the usual last minute panic just before the deadline
panic.translation[0].note_box[0].section: When the shooting started, there was panic.
There’s no need to get into a panic.
The innocent question threw her into a panic.
Suddenly, everything went dark and panic broke out.
Before panic could set in, she realised that the clock was fast.
Panic ensued as people ran out of the burning building.
She felt panic rising within her.
Panic spread as news of the invasion reached Paris.
There was a big panic about the virus last year.
She quickly packed a bag, trying all the time to control her mounting panic.
A wave of total panic swept across her.
He ran to the library in blind panic.
Florrie exclaimed in sudden panic: ‘I’ve left my bag on the bus!’
There was a note of mild panic in her voice.
She was in a constant state of panic that he would carry out his threat.
She looked out to sea with a rising sense of panic.
A sudden wave of panic overcame him.
He had had a panic attack in the street.
panic.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to suddenly feel so frightened that you cannot think clearly or behave sensibly, or to make someone do this
panic.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: He started to panic when he saw the gun.
Don’t panic! We’ll soon get you out of there.
The protests became more violent and many people were panicked into leaving the country.
panic.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a feeling of great fear and anxiety that makes you act without thinking
panic.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The stock market crash left an air of panic from which many individual investors still haven’t recovered.
By announcing future price increases, the administration touched off a consumer panic.
panic.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: when people are so anxious or worried about the future that they buy or sell goods, shares etc without thinking carefully first
panic.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Manila shares plunged 10.9% in panic selling.
At a supermarket in Brussels, panic buying got so furious that the managers stopped trying to put sugar, coffee and mineral water on the shelves.
panic.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to suddenly become so frightened and anxious that you do things without thinking clearly, or to make someone do this
panic.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Financial markets panicked, causing a run on the currency  (=causing the currency to lose a lot of its value).
Crowds of depositors, many panicked by fears they would lose their life savings, formed outside the banks.
